With eighteen lakes, budding fishermen will have plenty of tales to tell by the time the Travel Mode has been completed.

174235.Name: Morita no Saikyo Shogi
174235.Overview: Morita no Saikyou Shogi is a Board game, published by Random House, which was released in Japan in 1999. Shogi, also known as Japanese chess or the Game of Generals, is a two-player strategy board game native to Japan. In the same family as chess, makruk, shatranj, janggi and xiangqi, it is the most popular chess variant in Japan.

174236.Name: Pro Mahjong Kiwame D
174236.Overview: Pro Mahjong Kiwame D (プロ麻雀 極D) is a mahjong game for the Sega Dreamcast.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Tanaka Torahiko no Ultra-ryuu Shougi: Ibisha Anaguma-hen

174237.Name: Tanaka Torahiko no Uru Toraryuu Shogi: Ibisha Anaguma-hen
174237.Overview: Tanaka Torahiko no Uru Toraryuu Shogi: Ibisha Anaguma-hen (田中寅彦のウル寅流将棋 居飛車穴熊編) is a shogi game for the Sega Dreamcast.

174239.Name: James & Watch: Arm
174239.Overview: As an indie title produced by one person, James & Watch: Arm is light on the presentation, but what it does have is charm - and spades of it. Playing on the events of the fateful summer in 1972, you take control of youngest brother Mike as he is thrown through the air, and at certain points in his flight path you get the option to alter his course either left or right. By judging where the randomly positioned older brothers are located at the bottom of the screen, you get thrown back into the air and repeat the process. Every time you successfully land on one of the brothers, you gain a point. Miss though, and you land in a crumpled heap on the grass and receive one broken limb. Land three times...and it's game over. As Ben succinctly put it - you only have two arms! Arm is pretty basic in other respects - it has only one screen and simplistic (albeit authentic) sound effects, but it does feature VMU graphics and VGA support.

174240.Name: James & Watch: Tooth Cracker
174240.Overview:
As the name suggests, Tooth Cracker is once again based on the Nintendo Game & Watch and so features some fairly rudimentary graphics and sound effects. This shouldn't put you off though, as what worked in the 1980s still holds true today in this age of HD graphics and complex narratives - addictive gameplay and high scores are what made the Game & Watch a winner, and Tooth Cracker nails the formula with aplomb.

Gameplay is simple in the extreme - the cans move randomly along the line of teeth at the top of the screen, and when the moving fist below the can lines up you need to hit the action button. Line them up perfectly and you crack a tooth; miss and you lose a life. Each tooth takes three accurate hits with the can of Doggingtons' finest before shattering and if you get all of the teeth smashed you'll receive an extra life. As you get better at hitting the A button as the fist and the can line up, you'll be knocking teeth out for fun; but be aware that the game tempo speeds up as you progress meaning you're in for some pretty frantic reaction-based gameplay. There are two games modes (titled A and B), and the second mode introduces rotten black teeth that only require one direct hit to reduce them to putrid piles of black dust.

174259.Name: Beats of Rage Collection: Volume 1
174259.Overview:
Beats of Rage
Megaman War of the Past
Road Rash Revolution
Kill Ryu Volume 1
Kill Ryu Volume 2
Joe and Mac Caveman Ninja

174260.Name: Beats of Rage Collection: Volume 2
174260.Overview:
Beats of Rage Xtra
Double Dragon Extreme (Plus Version)
Dragon of Rage DC
Hatchet Ninjaz (Ex Version)
Hyper Final Fight 1 (v2)
Hyper Final Fight 2 (v2)
Rage of Streets (v5)
Alien Vs Predator: Aftermath
Beats of Rage Remixed

174261.Name: Beats of Rage Collection: Volume 3
174261.Overview:
Bare Knuckle: The Next Generation
Name Sailor V Code
Final Fight: The Last Round (Special Edition)
Golden Ax: Arcade Remake (Remix)
POW: Arcade Remake
Return of Double Dragon
Ryuko o NKen Nekketsu WII
Super Fightin' Spirit (Fixed)

174263.Name: D2 Shock Demo
174263.Overview:
This is a demo version of Warp's Dreamcast game D2. 

In Japan, a demonstration version of D2 was packaged with another Warp-produced game, the Dreamcast remake of the Sega Saturn title Real Sound: Kaze no Regret. This early preview of the game, known as D2 Shock Demo, features modified opening credits and a "heads up display" compared to the completed game. Additionally, it contains a save file that copies to the Dreamcast VMU and unlocks a "secret movie" in the retail Japanese version of D2. This movie is a preview of the shelved M2 version of D2. It was removed from the North American version but can briefly be seen as an in-flight movie during the hijacking sequence.

174264.Name: US Shenmue
174264.Overview: A special Japan-only edition of Shenmue in commemoration of the sale of more than 1 million units of the game. It is adapted from the North American release of Shenmue, containing English dialogue, loading screens, etc. It adds Japanese subtitles and notebook entries.

174367.Name: Kidou Senshi Gundam: Renpou vs. Zeon & DX
174367.Overview:
The game follows the Universal Century (UC) Gundam time line and takes place during the infamous One Year War. 
The player is able to pilot various mobile suits and characters from the original Mobile Suit Gundam television series. 
There are three gaming modes: 
Arcade mode, Versus mode, and Campaign mode. Arcade mode allows to select two mobile suits depending on the side of the conflict chosen (Earth Federation or Principality of Zeon ). The first mobile suit chosen is used for ground combat, while the second one is used in space environments. 
Versus mode allows two players to play on the same or opposing sides, with various maps and mobile suits available to choose from. 
The Campaign mode is centered around a player named soldier in the One Year War who combats the opposing side. Although in Campaign mode different mobile suits are unlocked as the campaign progresses. New mobile suits can be received by participating in test missions that involve that particular mobile suit. Exceptions are any captured enemy mobile suits, the Project V units (RX-78-2 Gundam, RX-75-4 Guntank, and RX-77-2 Guncannon), as well as all of Char Aznable's mobile suits (MS-06S Zaku II Commander Type, MSM-07S Z'Gok Commander Type, MS-14S Gelgoog Commander Type, and MSN-02 Zeong).

174383.Name: Canary : Kono Omoi o Uta ni Nosete

AlternateNames.AlternateName: イヴ·ゼロ 完全版 -Ark of the Matter-

174529.Name: Eve Zero Kanzenban: Ark of the Matter

174558.Name: Fushigi no Dungeon: Fuurai no Shiren Gaiden: Onna Kenshi Asuka Kenzan!

174654.Name: Kuon no Kizuna: Sairinshou
174654.Overview:
This story starts out from the perspective of a high school student. One day a transfer student comes to his school, and tells him she’ll kill him. At the same time, he starts seeing weird dreams and people mysteriously gets killed in his city.
Soon he realizes that them two are incarnated personalities of a man and a goddess that fell in love 1000 years ago. Since then, they have been trapped in a cycle of reincarnation and a battle against an evil god.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: サクラ大戦　花組対戦コラムス２

174973.Name: Sakura Taisen Online: Teito no Nagai Hibi

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.01: Bittersweet Fools: The Ren'ai Adventure
Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.01: Bittersweet Fools: The Ren'ai Adventure

174976.Name: Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.01: Bittersweet Fools: The Renai Adventure
174976.Overview: Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.01: Bitter Sweet Fools: The Renai Adventure is an entry in D3Publisher's Simple series of low-budget games, and the first of four to be released on the Sega Dreamcast. This entry is a port of Bittersweet Fools, a PC game by minori, with pornographic content removed. It was only released in Japan.

175034.Name: Sorcerian: Shichisei Mahou no Shito
175034.Overview:
Another remake of the classic RPG Sorcerian this time exclusive to the SEGA Dreamcast. Once again you must take control of a party of 4 player-created adventurers and lead them through 10 scenarios from the original game and 5 new ones specially designed for this version in a side-scrolling fashion, each featuring a unique stand-alone quest for you to complete.

The remake features for the first time in a Sorcerian game a fully polygonal engine, even if the game plays like a side-scroller while in the dungeons and from a top-down perspective in the town. Also included are new items, spells and job classes for your characters and the ability to enchant items and create your own spells while in town.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Angel Wish: Kimi no Hohoemi ni Chu!

176486.Name: Angel Wish: Kimi no Egao ni Chu!
176486.Overview: Angel Wish is an Adventure game, developed and published by Pione Soft, which was released in Japan in 2005.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Ao no 6-go Saigetsufutai Hito: Time and Tide
Ao no 6-gou: Saigetsu Hito o Matazu: Time and Tide
Blue Submarine No. 6: Time and Tide

176487.Name: Blue Submarine No. 6: Saigetsu Fumahito: Time and Tide
176487.Overview:
Blue Submarine No. 6: Saigetsu Fumahito- Time and Tide is an Adventure game, developed and published by Sega, which was released in Japan in 2000. 
It is based on the manga and anime series, Ao no 6-go, otherwise known as Blue Submarine No. 6.

176488.Name: Boko Yume no Tatsujin
176488.Overview: Boko Yume no Tatsujin is a Miscellaneous game, published by Fujicom, which was released in Japan in 2002.

176489.Name: Boku to, Bokura no Natsu
176489.Overview: Boku to Bokura no Natsu is an Adventure game, developed and published by Kid, which was released in Japan in 2002.

176490.Name: Cafe Little Wish: Mahou no Recipe
176490.Overview: Cafe Little Wish: Mahou no Recipe is an Adventure game, developed by Patissier and published by Princess Soft, which was released in Japan in 2003.

176491.Name: Canvas: Sepia Iro no Motif
176491.Overview: Asou Daisuke is a high school student and a gifted artist - but he is currently suffering from a block, which keeps him from painting. His childhood friend, Tachibana Amane, who loves him deeply, persuades him to do a portrait of Kimikage Yurina, a girl with a heart condition, before Yurina undergoes surgery. In the process of rediscovering his art, Daisuke also realises the love that he and Amane feel for each other.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Chou Hatsumei Boy Kanipan: Bousou Robot no Nazo!

176492.Name: Chou-Hatsumei Boy Kanipan: Bousou Robot no Nazo!?
176492.Overview: Chou-Hatsumei Boy Kanipan: Bousou Robot no Nazo!? is a Role-Playing game, published by Sega, which was released in Japan in 1999.

176493.Name: Christmas Seaman: Omoi o Tsutaeru Mou Hitotsu no Houhou
176493.Overview: Christmas Seaman is a festive upgrade to Seaman. It was released exclusively in Japan and was only available between 16 and 24 December 1999. Like the original Seaman it gives you the chance to raise your own pet, starting with nothing but a tiny egg? How about raise him to be a smart-mouthed, viper-tongued companion who listens to you and gives you a dose of smart-ass advice? Look no further than the lab of Dr. Jean Paul Gassé, who left you a few eggs from the mysterious creature known as the Seaman. Now you've got the chance to raise your very own Seaman. Talk to him, tickle him, feed him...just don't rub him the wrong way, or you'll end up with an angry pet and a big headache.

176495.Name: Boku, Doraemon
176495.Overview: Boku, Doraemon is an Adventure game, developed by Sega and published by Sega Toys, which was released in Japan in 2001.

176554.Name: Cherry Blossom
176554.Overview: Cherry Blossom is an Adventure game, developed and published by Takuyo, which was released in Japan in 2004.

176583.Name: Chocolat: Maid Cafe "Curio"
176583.Overview: Chocolat: Maid Cafe "Curio" (ショコラ 〜maid cafe “curio”〜) is a dating simulation for the Sega Dreamcast. Unlike the PC version, the Dreamcast version has no explicit content.

176584.Name: Close to: Inori no Oka
176584.Overview: Close to: Inori no Oka (Close to 〜祈りの丘〜) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

176621.Name: Comic Party
176621.Overview: Comic Party (こみっくパーティー) is a dating simulation for the Sega Dreamcast, originally released for Windows PCs. Explicit content from the original is removed in the Dreamcast version.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: CR Hissatsu Shigotonin: Pachitte Chonmage @ VP@CHI

176623.Name: CR Hissatsu Shigotonin Pachitte Chonmage @ VPACHI
176623.Overview: CR Hissatsu Shigotonin Pachitte Chonmage @VPACHI (CR必殺仕事人 パチってちょんまげ@VPACHI) is a pachinko game for the Sega Dreamcast. It is based on the television series Hissatsu Shigotonin.

176646.Name: Derby Tsuku 2
176646.Overview: Derby Tsuku 2 (ダビつく2) is a Sega Dreamcast horse racing training simulation released exclusively in Japan.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Dabi Tsuku: Derby Uma o Tsukurou!
Derby Tsuku: Derby Ba wo Tsukurou!

176647.Name: Derby Tsuku: Derby Uma o Tsukurou!
176647.Overview: Derby Tsuku: Derby Ba wo Tsukurou! (ダビつく ダービー馬をつくろう!) is an entry in Sega's Let's Make series for the Sega Dreamcast.

176949.Name: Erde: Nezu no Ki no Shita de
176949.Overview: Erde is a romance visual novel adventure game set in a near future with a slight fantasy elements. The gameplay, like in most visual novels, consists of reading through descriptions and dialogues, and selecting choices where presented which branch the story or take the events in a certain direction. The protagonist of the game is a village boy named Takumi. The game settings consist of an actual world which is set around the village Takumi lives in, and a virtual world which can be accessed using special bed-like terminals. One day, a girl on a motorcycle crashes into his house, leaving the hole in the wall. As chance has it, she'll need to stay until she fixes her bike and make it mobile again so she can get back on the road and see the world. Yoko's aspiration to see the world does not leave Takumi indifferent and he starts to ponder the idea himself.

176950.Name: GaiaMaster: Kessen! Seiki-ou Densetsu
176950.Overview:
As a willing participant in the game, a player chooses a hero from eight different characters including Jiggar the Treasure Hunter, who hunts for gems or Princess Tiara, she of the privileged class whose luck factor in the game awards her with bonus parcels of land.

Upon the throw of the dice, a player moves the allotted spaces on an expansive board broken up into squares. Landing on a property square opens up the option of purchasing it. Essentially, the player is joining the landlord class and may eventually build stores on his/her plots of land which doubles the rent other players have to pay if they land on it. Hoarding adjacent properties eventually helps to build up a mini-fiefdom which exacts payment from hapless opponents to build up the player's treasury.

Battles and events are also triggered when players land on certain squares, or when cards are thrown to ignite a fight. Capcom's monetary denomination is called Zenny, and it is present in games from Forgotten Worlds to Mega Man Legends. It also pays the rent in Gaia Master. At the end of the day, the player with the most Zenny wins.

176951.Name: Grauen no Torikago: Kapitel 2: Torikago
176951.Overview: Grauen no Torikago Kapitel 2: Torikago (グラウエンの鳥籠 Kapitel 2 「鳥籠」) is the second chapter of Grauen no Torikago movie. It contains about 60 episodes.

176952.Name: Grauen no Torikago: Kapitel 3: Kansei
176952.Overview: Grauen no Torikago Kapitel 3: Kansei (グラウエンの鳥籠 Kapitel 3 「陥穽」) is the third chapter of Grauen no Torikago movie. It contains about 60 episodes of one minute each.

176953.Name: Grauen no Torikago: Kapitel 4: Kaikou
176953.Overview: Grauen no Torikago Kapitel 4: Kaikou (グラウエンの鳥籠 Kapitel 4 「邂逅」) is the fourth chapter of Grauen no Torikago movie. It contains about 60 episodes of one minute each.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Marie & Elie no Atelier: Salberg no Renkinjutsushi 1 & 2

176958.Name: Atelier Marie + Elie: The Alchemists of Salburg 1・2
176958.Overview: Marie & Elie no Atelier: Salberg no Renkinjutsushi 1-2 (マリー＆エリーのアトリエ 〜ザールブルグの錬金術士１･２〜) is an compilation for the Sega Dreamcast, containing enhanced versions of Marie no Atelier: Salburg no Renkinjutsushi (1997) and Elie no Atelier: Salburg no Renkinjutsushi 2 (1998).

176959.Name: Mei ☆ Puru
176959.Overview: Mei ☆ Puru (めい☆ぷる) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Resident Evil Code: Veronica: Trial Edition

176960.Name: Biohazard Code: Veronica: Trial Edition
176960.Overview:
A demo of CODE: Veronica was included with Biohazard 2 Value Plus on the 
Dreamcast to sell consumers on the minimally upgraded re-release of the 
original PlayStation game (actually ported from PC). The demo contained 
most of the first fifteen minutes of the game, along with all the cut-
scenes that made it to the final game in that portion. 

The only change is that Claire is able to take the Gold Lugers from the 
display room in the Palace, compared to the final game, in which Steve 
takes them instead. Claire can take the Lugers to the door in the save 
room on the second floor, and unlock it by placing the Lugers onto 
there. In the final game, Claire could only do this after going through 
the Airport and Military Training Facility. The demo ends with Claire 
headed towards the Private Residence, and hearing Alexia laughing. 

The demo also contains a few music tracks from all the Biohazard games 
up to that point in 1999 (so it excludes Gun Survivor).

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Nishikaze no Kyoushikyoku: The Rhapsody of Zephyr

177006.Name: Nishikaze no Rhapsody
177006.Overview: Nishikaze no Rhapsody (西風の狂詩曲～The Rhapsody of Zephyr～), also known as The Rhapsody of Zephyr, is a tactical RPG for the Sega Dreamcast.

177007.Name: Nobunaga no Yabou: Reppuden
177007.Overview: Nobunaga no Yabou: Reppuden (信長の野望 烈風伝) is a simulation game for the Sega Dreamcast, and is part of the long-running Nobunaga no Yabou series.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: You That Became a Memory ~Memories Off~

177013.Name: Omoide ni Kawaru Kimi: Memories Off
177013.Overview:
Omoide ni Kanata Kimi: Memories Off (想い出にかわる君 ~メモリーズオフ~, lit. You That Became a Memory ~Memories Off~) is a Japanese romance visual novel developed by KID for the Dreamcast and the PlayStation. It is the third game in the Memories Off series. The game was released for the Dreamcast and the PlayStation on September 27, 2001. It was later ported to the PlayStation 2 and PlayStation Portable. It was adapted into the first tale of an OVA series, titled as "Memories Off 3.5: Omoide no Kanata e".

Shougo is a lazy university student. He used to have a girlfriend called Kanata Kurosu, but one day she left him and he didn't know anything about her. One day, he meets her at the Cubic Cafe, Shougo's usual relax spot, and a new story beings...

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Oogami Ichirou Funtou-ki: Sakura Taisen Kayou Show Beni Tokage yori

177017.Name: Ogami Ichiro Funtouki: Sakura Taisen Kayou Show "Benitokage" Yori
177017.Overview: Ogami Ichiro Funtouki: Sakura Taisen Kayou Show "Benitokage" Yori (大神一郎奮闘記～サクラ大戦歌謡ショウ『紅蜥蜴』より～) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast. It is a story about the actors who took part in the various Sakura Taisen stage shows at the time.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Ouka Houshin: Ouka Saki shi Toki

177020.Name: Oukahouzin: Ouka Sakishi Toki
177020.Overview: Oukahouzin: Ouka Sakishi Toki (央華封神 〜央華咲きし刻〜) is a simulation RPG for the Sega Dreamcast.

177021.Name: Pizzicato Polka: Ensa Genya
177021.Overview: Pizzicato Polka: Ensa Genya (ピチカートポルカ 〜縁鎖現夜〜) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast.

177022.Name: Shinseiki Evangelion: Typing Hokan Keikaku
177022.Overview: Shinseiki Evangelion: Typing Hokan Keikaku (新世紀エヴァンゲリオン タイピング補完計画) is a game for the Sega Dreamcast which uses the Dreamcast Keyboard. Its gameplay resembles the likes of The Typing of the Dead.

177025.Name: Saka Tsuku Tokudaigou 2: J. League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurou!
177025.Overview: Saka Tsuku Tokudaigou 2: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurou! (サカつく特大号２ Ｊ．ＬＥＡＧＵＥプロサッカークラブをつくろう！) is a Sega Dreamcast entry in the Let's Make series and a sequel to Saka Tsuku Tokudaigou: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurou!.

177026.Name: Sakura Momoko Gekijou: Coji Coji
177026.Overview: Sakura Momoko Gekijou: Coji Coji (さくらももこ劇場 コジコジ) is a game for the Sega Dreamcast. It is based on the anime series of the same name.

177028.Name: Sengoku Turb: Fanfan I love me Dunce-doublentendre
177028.Overview:
Sengoku Turb: Fanfan I love me Dunce-doublentendre (戦国TURB Fanfan I ♥ me Dunce-doublentendre) is a follow-up to Sengoku Turb, also released exclusively in Japan in 1999. It appears to be nothing more than a minigame collection hidden underneath the veil of an RPG.

Sega of Japan's catalogue page refers to the game as Sengoku Turb: Fanfan I love me Dance-doubletendre, correcting the misspelt "dance" but missing a letter from "entendre".[2] It also abbreviates the name to Sengoku Turb F.I.D..

177030.Name: Shirotsumesouwa: Episode of the Clovers
177030.Overview: Shirotsumesouwa: Episode of the Clovers (白詰草話 -エピソード・オブ・ザ・クローバーズ-) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

177047.Name: Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.04: Okaeritsu!: The Renai Adventure
177047.Overview: Simple 2000 Series DC Vol.04: Okaeritsu!: The Renai Adventure (SIMPLE 2000シリーズDC Vol.04 おかえり! THE恋愛アドベンチャー) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast. It is a port of the PlayStation game Simple 1500 Series Vol. 81: The Renai Adventure, originally developed by S-Neo. HuneX developed the Sega Dreamcast port one year later.

177049.Name: Sister Princess Premium Edition
177049.Overview:
Sister Princess Premium Edition (シスター･プリンセス プレミアム･エディション) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast. 
 
The game itself plays out like a dating sim. Players have about a month to spend with the sisters with each day broken up into three segments: first is the free time period before noon, followed by the period after lunch and ending with another period of time before bed. During day time, the player can choose which of the girls he wishes to escort to school, if any. The period after lunch is similar to the one in the morning, with additional choices which allow the player to go to various places in town besides walking home with one of the girls. Every night before bed, the player will be allowed to check his e-mail and send replies. As the player continues to interact with the sisters, their reactions to their big brother will change accordingly until the ending. According to one source, there are two different endings for each sister: the normal ending and the "non-blood relation" ending. As the name would suggest, the special ending reveals that the brother-character and sister aren't actually related by blood. In the case of some of the older sisters, this can lead to the protagonist and "sister" marrying one another. In Sister Princess 1, the player can see two different endings for each sister, but Sister Princess 2 has four endings for each sister. The first two were the non-sibling relation and siblings-together ending and, if the player chooses one sister in the beginning but ends up with another sister, either of the other two endings for the first sister who the player does not choose appear ("non-blood relation" ending and "still brother and sister forever" ending also) but with a different story. Sister Princess is one of the few popular dating game series that does not feature hentai elements. Despite (or perhaps because of) this, a rival company known as GIGA decided to create the hentai knockoff Colorful Kiss. While this game features a different cast of characters (to avoid lawsuits), their setup and personalities are comparable. Colorful Kiss was popular enough to warrant the sequel Colorful Heart. It is important to note that these GIGA titles are ultimately incestuous.

177050.Name: Sonic Adventure 2: The Trial
177050.Overview:
Sonic Adventure 2: The Trial, not to be confused with Sonic Adventure 2: Trial Version, is a free demo of Sonic Adventure 2 for the Sega Dreamcast, which was bundled with releases of Phantasy Star Online. It is an earlier prototype than Sonic Adventure 2 (Preview).

Sonic Adventure 2: The Trial includes one level (City Escape) from Sonic Adventure 2, with dialogue spoken completely in Japanese, accompanied by English subtitles. The translation for the opening helicopter escape cutscene is also slightly different - in this demo, one of the pilots exclaims, "What the hell?", while in the final version, this line was changed to, "What in the world?".

This demo differs in several ways from the final version, the most notable difference being that Sonic still wears his original trademark shoes. It wasn't until a few months before the retail release of Sonic Adventure 2 that Sonic Team revealed a merchandising deal with Soap Shoes. Other changes in Sonic Adventure 2: The Trial include a different logo, different road-side billboards, different sound effects, looser controls and physics, and an instrumental version of the song, Escape from the City.

When the player waits through the title screen, a video plays. This video shows prototype footage, including Sonic in Sky Rail, which Sonic does not access in the final version of Sonic Adventure 2.

177051.Name: Suigetsu: Mayoigokoro
177051.Overview: Suigetsu: Mayoigokoro (水月 〜迷心〜) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast.

177052.Name: Tenohira wo, Taiyou Ni
177052.Overview: Tenohira wo, Taiyou Ni (てのひらを、たいように) is a Sega Dreamcast adventure game.

177053.Name: Tentama: 1st Sunny Side
177053.Overview: Tentama: 1st Sunny Side (てんたま −ファーストサニーサイド−) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast.

177054.Name: Tsuki wa Higashi ni Hi wa Nishi ni: Operation Sanctuary
177054.Overview:
Tsuki wa Higashi ni Hi wa Nishi ni: Operation Sanctuary (月は東に日は西に -Operation Sanctuary-, The Moon in the East, The Sun in the West -Operation Sanctuary-), known as Hanihani (はにはに) for short, is a Japanese adult visual novel developed by August. It was released on July 20, 2003 for Windows using the NScripter engine. The Dreamcast and PlayStation 2 versions were released by Alchemist in 2004. An anime adaptation was broadcast in Japan in 2004, and originally ran from June 30, to September 22.The title references a haiku by Yosa Buson: "Nanohana ya tsuki wa higashi ni hi wa nishi ni."

Naoki Kazumi is a boy whose parents died in an accident five years ago, and his memory went along with it. Since he had nowhere else to go, he lives with his cousin Matsuri Shibugaki and her parents. Every morning before school, he is awakened by his childhood friend, Honami Fujieda, who keeps telling him that he is not a child anymore, but still comes to wake him up. These usual, ordinary days seem to stretch on forever, until one day up on the school's rooftop, while Naoki is taking a peaceful nap, out of nowhere, a girl falls out of the sky. This girl, called Mikoto Amagasaki, comes from 100 years in the future, and she went back in time with the intention of finding her brother. When Mikoto sees Naoki, she mistakes him for her brother.

177056.Name: Weakness Hero Torauman DC
177056.Overview: Weakness Hero Torauman DC (ウィークネスヒーロー トラウマンＤＣ) is a simulation game for the Sega Dreamcast.

177057.Name: Wind: A Breath of Heart
177057.Overview:
Wind: A Breath of Heart (ウインド ア ブレス オブ ハート) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast. The game follows Makoto Okano (丘野 真) as he returns to his hometown after 10 years away. Before he left, he and Minamo Narukaze (鳴風 みなも) made a promise to each other to meet again. She told him she will keep on playing the harmonic and even though he may be too far away to see it, the wind will carry the melody, hopefully all the way to his place.

Ten long years have passed, and together with his younger sister, Hinata Okano (丘野 ひなた), Makoto returns to his hometown. One evening, after school classes, he hears a melody that attracts his attention, which in turn leads him to the roof where he sees a girl with a purple hair, playing a harmonica. Not realizing at first who she is, the truth soon becomes clear that the girl is none other than Minamo, and promise of their reunion has been fulfilled via serendipity, but that is just the beginning of their story.

177058.Name: World Neverland 2 Plus: Pluto Kyouwakoku Monogatari
177058.Overview: World Neverland 2 Plus: Pluto Kyouwakoku Monogatari (ワールド・ネバーランド2 プラス ～プルト共和国物語～) is a simulation game for the Sega Dreamcast. It is an enhanced version of World Neverland 2, originally released on the PlayStation and sequel to World Neverland Plus: Orurudo Oukoku Monogatari, also released for the Dreamcast.

177083.Name: Merge: Marginal
177083.Overview: Merge: Marginal (マージ 〜MARGINAL〜) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast, originally released for Windows PCs. Explicit content from the original is removed in the Dreamcast version.

178610.Name: Love Hina: Smile Again
178610.Overview:
Love Hina: Smile Again is an adventure game based on the Love Hina franchise for the Sega Dreamcast.

The gameplay is mostly just dialogue, but it has a few mini-games and the storyline can be changed based on a luck system. You take control over Keitaro and talk with the girls in Hinata House.

178611.Name: Kidou Senkan Nadesico: Nadesico the Mission
178611.Overview: Kidou Senkan Nadesico: Nadesico the Mission is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast based on the Kidou Senkan Nadesico franchise. It continues the story from Prince of Darkness.

178707.Name: Halo Revamped
178707.Overview: Halo Revamped is a port of the PSP quake mod “Halo Revamped” for Dreacmast running under the makaqu engine.

178731.Name: Resident Evil: Code: Veronica X
178731.Overview:
This is the same as the original Resident Evil: Code: Veronica for Dreamcast, with new cut-scenes that were not included in the original. Also, Steve got a haircut.

The game is otherwise almost the same, you still take control of Claire Redfield and Chris Redfield, who are searching for each other, while uncovering the secrets behind the Umbrella Corporation.

180052.Name: Arcade Racing Legends
180052.Overview:
(from official website pixelheart.eu)
Get your old Dreamcast’s engine warmed up and show off your driving skills as you take the wheel of one of the dozens of legendary cars included in Arcade Racing Legends game!

At full speed, on an original soundtrack you will try to control your vehicle on 6 varied circuits (city, desert…).
Face your friends in frenzied games thanks to the “Duel” mode or take up the challenges of the “Career” mode.
Train and improve your skills to unlock additional features. Need more perfection? A Time Trial mode is here to let you know every turn on the joystick tip and take on your shadow!

Independent retro game of the year, developed for the 20th anniversary of the console by the publisher PixelHeart and financed via Kickstarter with more than 300 contributors.

Features:
– Duel 2 players
– Career Mode
– Time Trial Race
– More than 15 vehicles
– 6 Circuits
– Original musics Electro, Punk/Rock

180257.Name: Jet Coaster Dream 2
180257.Overview:
A sequel to "Jet Coaster Dream", known as Coaster Works outside of Japan, "Jet Coaster Dream 2" expands the roller coaster building aspects of the first game to include more management of the park itself. 

The game was originally set for release in the US and Europe, but was cancelled in 2001 due to the discontinuation of the Sega Dreamcast.

180263.Name: Treasure Strike
180263.Overview: Treasure Strike (トレジャーストライク) is an action game for the Sega Dreamcast. An @barai version of this game was once planned, but never materialized.

181144.Name: Yume no Tsubasa: Fate of Heart
181144.Overview: Yume no Tsubasa: Fate of Heart (夢のつばさ 〜フエイトオブハート〜) is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

181145.Name: Yoshia no Oka de Nekoronde...
181145.Overview: Yoshia no Oka de Nekoronde... is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast. The main character used to be a best-seller writer but lost the ability to write good stories after getting a disability. He decides to go to the hot springs resort to find his hidden self and try to get rid of his deficiency.

181150.Name: Generator Vol. 1
181150.Overview:
Generator Vol. 1 is a demo disc containing preview versions of various Sega Dreamcast games released in 1999 It was only available in North America as was bundled with early Dreamcast consoles.
Playable Demos - Ready 2 Rumble Boxing, Power Stone, Monaco Grand Prix, The House of the Dead 2, Sonic Adventure, Sega Bass Fishing, Flag to Flag

AlternateNames.AlternateName: スーパーロボット大戦α

181187.Name: Super Robot Taisen Alpha for Dreamcast
181187.Overview: The Dreamcast release features fully-3D models rather than the sprite-based graphics of the original, and also includes a number of balance tweaks to make the game more difficult, along with a new secret boss.

181188.Name: Suika
181188.Overview: Suika (水夏 〜SUIKA〜) is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast.

181190.Name: Snow
181190.Overview: The story of Snow starts when the main protagonist Kanata Izumo revisits a small village from his childhood called Ryūjin-mura (龍神村, lit. "Dragon God Village"). He is revisiting Ryūjin-mura to help manage a local inn with hot springs, Ryūjin Tenshukaku (龍神天守閣, lit. "Dragon God Keep"), alongside his cousin Tsugumi. In the village, there is an old legend: In ancient times, Ryūjin-mura was protected by the dragon goddess. However, one day the goddess fell in love with a human, which is strictly forbidden, and this incident caused the village to be always covered by snow after that. The game then tells the daily life of Kanata interacting with the village girls and ultimately links the story to the legend. Snow follows a branching plot line with multiple endings, and depending on the decisions that the player makes during the game, the plot will progress in a specific direction.

181192.Name: The Shinri Game
181192.Overview: The Shinri Game (ザ・心理ゲーム) is a quiz game.

181445.Name: Es
181445.Overview: es is a realistic Japanese psycho-drama. The government is working on a project, attempting to extract a serial killer's memory and inject it into another person's mind. The player control such ambiguous mind made of two persons. The game is based on a Japanese TV show and has very little interactivity.

181448.Name: Dabi Tsuku: Derby Uma o Tsukurou!

181450.Name: Shin Nihon Pro Wrestling: Toukon Retsuden 4
181450.Overview: Shin Nihon Pro Wrestling Toukon Retsuden 4 (新日本プロレスリング 闘魂烈伝4) is a 1999 wrestling game for the Sega Dreamcast by Tomy Entertainment and Yuke's. It is the fourth and final main entry in the Shin Nihon Pro Wrestling Toukon Retsuden series, whose previous three entries were exclusive to the PlayStation. 4 breaks tradition by being a Dreamcast exclusive instead.

181451.Name: Revive...: Sosei
181451.Overview: Revive...: Sosei (リバイヴ･･･ 〜蘇生〜) is a point & click adventure for the Sega Dreamcast, originally released for Windows PCs. It is the sequel to Doukoku Soshite... for the Sega Saturn. Explicit content from the original is removed from the Dreamcast version.

181452.Name: Dejiko no Maibura
181452.Overview: Dejiko no Maibura (でじこのまいブラ) is not actually a game at all but is an internet tool for the Sega Dreamcast. It based on Dream Passport 3.

181454.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 1
181454.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 1 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol. 1) isn't a full game, it is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #1999-07-23. Disk of the same content has been distributed only in postage by NEC Home Electronics.
Playable Demos - Sengoku Turb, Seventh Cross F.I.D. / Video Demos - Industrial Spy: Operation Espionage

181455.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 2
181455.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 2 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol. 2) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #1999-08-27.
Playable Demos Disc 1 - Cool Boarders Burrrn, Buggy Heat / Playable Demos Disc 2 - Soulcalibur

181456.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 3
181456.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 3 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.3) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #1999-11-26.
Playable Demos - Shinkisekai Evolution 2: Tooi Yakusoku, Death Crimson 2: Meranito no Saidan, Bakuretsu Muteki Bangaioh, Vermilion Desert, Berserk, Golf Shiyouyo, Oukahouzin: Ouka Sakishi Toki

181457.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 4
181457.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 4 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.4) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #1999-12-24.
Playable Demos - D-2

181458.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 7
181458.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 7 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.7) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2000-09-29.
Playable Demos - DeSpiria, Outtrigger, 18 Wheeler: American Pro Trucker / Videos - Illbleed Trailer Movie, Capcom vs. SNK: Millennium Fight 2000 Special Movie

181460.Name: Happy Breeding
181460.Overview: Happy Breeding (DC) also known as Happy Breeding: Cheerful Party (PS2) is a non-adult console port of a Happy Breeding adult visual novel for PC (Windows). While the original game had voice-acting, the console ports changed voice-actresses for some of the heroines. The story revolves around Takashi, who just started living on his own recently. One day, he finds a strange looking girl in his house and ends up living together, seeing how the house was too big for one person and all. It doesn't go too long before he finds himself living together with yet another girl, and yet another. All the girls are not entirely human and display animal traits such as dog's ears, cat's tails, and the likes. Thus his life on his own soon turns out more lively than he expected after leaving his parents. The game is a typical visual novel with basic features of the genre, static characters which only vary in poses, occasional animations such as rain effect, sound effect to indicate what is happening on the scene instead of seeing actual animations, fast-forward option during dialogues, and full voice-acting, but only for main heroines.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: ハローキティの「音なる」メール

181461.Name: Hello Kitty no Otonaru Mail
181461.Overview: Ever wanted you open your mail in a Virtua Kitty world? Well now's your chance in this mail application software by Sega.

181462.Name: Iris
181462.Overview:
Iris is one of Kid's romantic visual novels with a school setting. This story centers around junior high-school students in their final year and takes place in a town called Hisame-cho during winter time. This visual novel focuses on the story of one's first love. You are Haruki Setohara, a third year junior high-school student, and by selecting different choices in the story, you focus your affections toward the girl of your choice. Leading female characters you get in contact with are Sakura, your classmate, Shinonome, Sakura's close friend, Yui, a junior high school graduate who lives next door, Miu, a first year junior high-school student, Manami, your class president, and Natsumi, your cousin and also your classroom teacher.

The story branches based on player's choices which are presented at key points in the story. It features many options regarding the style menu for visual design, and sound menu where you can setup the music and even turn on/off voice-acting for an individual female characters. As you play the game, many extras are unlocked which can be accessed from the main menu. Extras include CG artwork, background music, opening cinematic, and a list of the cleared chapters.

181465.Name: Princess Maker Collection
181465.Overview: Princess Maker Collection is a compilation for the Sega Dreamcast containing Princess Maker 2 and Princess Maker: Yumemiru Yousei.

181466.Name: Doguu Senki: Haou
181466.Overview: Doguu Senki: Haou is a turn-based strategy game for the Sega Dreamcast.

181468.Name: Interlude
181468.Overview: Interlude is a 2003 visual novel by LONGSHOT for the Sega Dreamcast released exclusively in Japan

181837.Name: Grauen no Torikago: Kapitel 6: Senritsu
181837.Overview: Grauen no Torikago Kapitel 6: Senritsu (グラウエンの鳥籠 Kapitel 6 「戦慄」) is the last chapter of Grauen no Torikago movie. It contains about 60 episodes of one minute each. Not only is Senritsu the rarest of the six discs in the series, it is often cited as one of the rarest Dreamcast discs in existence.

181872.Name: Dousoukai 2: Again & Refrain
181872.Overview:
Again and Refrain are originally two standalone PC games from the same series, but ported to Dreamcast they were released as a single standalone game that includes both scenarios. Dreamcast platform does not have these games released as standalone.

Dousoukai 2: Again & Refrain Dreamcast game contains scenarios from these two PC games:

Dousoukai: Again
Dousoukai: Refrain

181873.Name: Ever 17: the out of infinity: Premium Edition
181873.Overview:
Ever 17: the out of infinity: Premium Edition is an updated rerelease of Ever 17: the out of infinity released by KID for the Sega Dreamcast in 2003

The game is set in a huge futuristic water amusement park. Built on the ocean, this park is technology's latest word, and is at the first sight the most fascinating and secure construction of all. However, something goes wrong, and seven people - two boys and five girls - become trapped in the park. The danger increases as they face a mysterious virus that brings them on the verge of death.

The player controls two different characters: Takeshi Kuranari, a simple, normal Japanese teenager, and a mysterious boy with amnesia, who cannot even remember his name. The relationship between the characters becomes more and more tense as the story develops. Will the young people be able to solve the mystery and escape death?

Ever17 is the second game in KID's Infinity series. The game is not connected to Never7: The End of Infinity either by storyline or protagonists, but both games share the same "dreamy", semi-futuristic setting, and their stories have a similar style. The gameplay of Ever17 is that of a visual novel: the player reads dialogues and watches scenes, viewing them as one of the two protagonists, occasionally having to make decision as to what to do next and how to answer in a conversation. Those decisions influence the course of the story and lead to different endings.

181880.Name: Kaitou Apricot
181880.Overview: Kaitou Apricot is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

181881.Name: Kaze no Uta
181881.Overview:
Kaze no Uta (aka Song of the Wind) is a visual novel erotic adventure game with explicit content. The story takes place in a small rural area around the seaside town called Sakuragi-cho. The protagonist returns from Tokyo to spend the summer in a town which brings him a lot of nostalgic memories. But after being absent for so long, unaware about the current events in the town, the summer vacations may not be so carefree and relaxing as you expect them to be.

The Dreamcast port was release two years after initial Windows release, and is adjusted for consoles as it removes all the adult content. It adds however new CG events to the gameplay and also includes bonus drama disc. There is also a DVD-Player game release which is more similar to the original game and features all the adult content.

181882.Name: Kimi ga Nozomu Eien
181882.Overview: Kimi ga Nozomu Eien is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast, originally released for Windows PCs. Explicit content from the original is removed in the Dreamcast version.

181883.Name: Majo no Ochakai
181883.Overview: Majo no Ochakai is a visual novel for the Sega Dreamcast.

181884.Name: Mizu Iro
181884.Overview:
Mizu Iro was originally released as an adult visual-novel, which yielded this console port for PlayStation 2 and Dreamcast two years later. The game follows the story of Kenji Katase, a high-school student who lives with his adopted sister, Yuki. One day, Kenji's childhood friend, Hiyori Hayasaka, re-appears in his life and his long-gone feelings of affection toward her started to awaken.

As is the case with many romance-driven visual novels, your choices will determine how the story branches, and your actions will drive the story toward the heroine of your interest. While this console game version removed the adult content, it added additional character and story content with new CG events. As you play through the games, you unlock CG gallery for heroines which is accessible via main menu, along with the music player.

181886.Name: Nobunaga no Yabou: Shouseiroku with Power-Up Kit
181886.Overview: Nobunaga no Yabou: Shouseiroku with Power-Up Kit is a 1999 game by Koei for the Sega Dreamcast. It is a expanded version of Nobunaga no Yabou Shouseiroku, released a year earlier on the Sega Saturn — for some reason, Koei released the Power-Up Kit as a port rather than on the same console (which they did with other Power-Up Kits). The regular version of the game was not released on Dreamcast.

181887.Name: Pia Carrot e Youkoso!! 2.5
181887.Overview:
Pia Carrot e Youkoso!! 2.5 is an adventure game released by NEC Interchannel for the Sega Dreamcast.

Welcome to Pia Carrot!! 2.2 is a branch of "Pia Carrot 2" and is set 4 months after that game. It was released for the Game Boy Color by NEC Interchannel in 2000. Welcome to Pia Carrot!! 2.5 is a combination set of "Pia Carrot 2" and "Pia Carrot 2.2" for the Dreamcast. This pack title contains 2 GD-ROMs.

181888.Name: Utau: Tumbling Dice
181888.Overview:
Utau: Tumbling Dice is an adventure game for the Sega Dreamcast.

This console port of Utau: Tumbling Dice game for PC (Windows) has features 2 new characters and expanded story that include new characters.

181896.Name: Gundam Side Story 0079: Rise from the Ashes Premium Disc
181896.Overview: Gundam Side Story 0079: Rise from the Ashes Premium Disc is an expansion pack for Gundam Side Story 0079: Rise from the Ashes. It was distributed free by Bandai. The disc contains the sham battle stage with Gundam RX-78, and some extra options.

182226.Name: Real Sound: Kaze no Regret
182226.Overview: Warp's president, Kenji Eno, created the game after receiving numerous appreciation letters from blind fans of his games in Japan. Eno visited a number of his visually disabled fans to learn how it is that blind people could play the visually rich action game genre.

182228.Name: Milky Season
182228.Overview:
In Milky Season, the player controls a young student who got appointed as the head of the girls' dormitory. This, in turn, will put you into many awkward and romantic situations where you can select how the story will branch and which girl you may fall in love with, based on your choices during dialogues. Milky Season is a visual novel that originated on consoles (PlayStation and Dreamcast), and is not a PC port and as such had no adult elements to begin with, focusing more on the story and interaction with the characters in this slice-of-life sort of setting.

The game features twelve heroines, letting you check the affection of 8 possible love interests towards you at any point during the game. The game does not feature any animation and characters depict their attitude and disposition only in voice-acting and static poses. Typical visual novel elements are present during gameplay, such as the dialogue text can be toggled to see the clear background, or that your choices may lead you towards a certain path in the story. The twelve heroines you can interact with in the game are: Miki Ayase, Saori Nonohana, Marin Chiura, Chihaya Hoshinami, Yun Usami, Reika Ranzaki, Mio Ayase, Itsuki Fujiwara, Mashiro Tachibana, Urumi Morishita, Kasumi Shindou, and Sachie Tohyama.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: サクラ大戦キネマトロン 花組メール

182231.Name: Sakura Taisen Kinematron Hana-gumi Mail
182231.Overview: A piece of Sega Dreamcast software distributed exclusively with Sakura Taisen-branded Dreamcasts which is essentially a glorified emailing service, where the user can send emails with Sakura Taisen imagery. In order for the recipient to see the added features, he/she must also own this disc, otherwise the email will be rendered simply as text (which effectively means the recipient must own a Sakura Taisen Dreamcast). Given the state of the Dreamcast's online capabilities in the modern age, the disc is largely unusable today.

183107.Name: Street Fighter Zero 3: Saikyo-ryu Dojo for Matching Service

183110.Name: Tokusatsu Bouken Katsugeki Super Hero Retsuden
183110.Overview: Tokusatsu Bouken Katsugeki Super Hero Retsuden is an Adventure game, developed by ALU and published by Banpresto, which was released in Japan in 2000. Gameplay is quite unique as it runs like a side-scrolling, turn-based beat 'em up with lots of dialogue in between the battles.

183111.Name: Net de Tennis
183111.Overview: Net de Tennis or Netto de Tennis (ねっとdeテニス) is a tennis budget title released for the Dreamcast exclusively in Japan. It shares many similarities to Smash Stars, the tennis portion of the game Capcom Sports Club.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Renai Chu!: Kanojo no Himitsu wa Otoko no Ko? - Happy Perfect (Shokai Genteiban)

183121.Name: DreamFlyer
183121.Overview: DreamFlyer (ドリームフライヤー) is a piece of Japanese Sega Dreamcast software allowing users to customise and send digital greetings cards over the internet.

183124.Name: Orange Pocket: Cornet
183124.Overview: A console port of a PC (Windows) hentai visual novel Orange Pocket. While the adult content scenes were removed, rating reduced, and story adjusted to work without them, the console ports feature additional story scenario and new event CG scenes. Both console versions feature one new exclusive heroine. For PlayStation 2 that is Arika Minamoto (源 ありか) and for Dreamcast version that is Korone Kawanami (川波 ころね).

183196.Name: Kita He: Photo Memories
183196.Overview: Kita e. Photo Memories (北へ。Photo Memories) is a visual novel released for the Sega Dreamcast by Hudson Soft as part of the Kita e. series.

183954.Name: Dream On Volume 2
183954.Overview:
Dream On Volume 2 is a Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed in Europe as part of the Dream On series. It was sold with issue #1 of the UK's Official Dreamcast Magazine, issue #x of Dreamcast: Le Magazine Officiel and issue #1 of Dreamcast: Das Offizielle Magazin. Volume 2 was the first Dream On demo disc to be sold exclusively with magazines.

Dream On Volume 2 contains two playable demos, four movies and a "rolling demo" of Buggy Heat, in which the game isn't playable, but the footage is rendered in real-time. The Millennium Soldier: Expendable demo lets the player play through the first stage, and the Sonic Adventure demo lets players (as Sonic) run through Emerald Coast. The Sonic Adventure demo is particularly common, having been put to work in Generator Vol. 1 and Generator Vol. 2 in North America, kiosks scattered across the world to promote the Dreamcast system, as well as future Dream On demo discs.

183955.Name: Dreamcast Express Vol. 1
183955.Overview:
Dreamcast Express Vol. 1 is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc released as part of the Dreamcast Express series.
Playable Demos - Aero Dancing featuring Blue Impulse, Buggy Heat, Pop'n Music / Videos - Geist Force (Sega), Gamera Dream Battle for the VMU (Sega), Marvel vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes (Capcom), Psychic Force 2012 (Taito), Puyo Puyo 4 (Sega) / Other - Shenmue gifts, Shenmue Premiere, Making Yukawa promotion video, Blue Stinger

183956.Name: Dreamstudio
183956.Overview: Dreamstudio (ドリームスタジオ) is a piece of Dreamcast software which allows the user to create video games. It was released exclusively in Japan. Games created with Dreamstudio are more often than not restricted by the 128kB of VMU storage space. There is also a lot of text input, so the game recommends a Dreamcast Keyboard.

186166.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 5
186166.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 5 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.5) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2000-07-07.
Playable Demos - Mr. Driller, Zusar Vasar, Derby Tsuku: Derby Ba wo Tsukurou! / Demo Videos - Jet Set Radio, Sega's game is world class

186168.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 6
186168.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 6 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.6) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2000-08-11.
Playable Demos - Cool Cool Toon, Mercurius Pretty: End of the Century, F355 Challenge, Cyber Troopers Virtual-On: Oratorio Tangram M.S.B.S. Ver. 5.66 / Videos Grandia II

186169.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 8
186169.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 8 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.8) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2000-11-27.
Playable Demos - Power Smash, Guilty Gear X, Marionette Handler 2 / Videos - Tricolore Crise, Moero! Justice Gakuen

186170.Name: Dream Preview Vol. 8
186170.Overview:
Dream Preview Vol. 8 (ドリーム プレピュー Vol.8) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast promotional disc containing footage of upcoming games.
Videos - Speed Devils, Super Producers: Mezase Show Biz Kai, Plus Plum, Rune Caster, Nihon Pro Mahjong Renmei Kounin: Tetsuman Menkyokaiden, Yume Baken '99 Internet, Shenmue, Revive...: Sosei, Marionette Company, Carrier, Zombie Revenge

186370.Name: Generator Vol. 2
186370.Overview:
Generator Vol. 2 is a "sequel" to Generator Vol. 1, and is a demo disc containing preview versions of various Sega Dreamcast games released in 1999 and 2000. It was only available in North America as it was bundled with Dreamcast consoles, although the majority of the demos found their way onto other demo discs across the globe.
Playable Demos - Sonic Adventure, Tomb Raider: The Last Revelation, Fur Fighters, Railroad Tycoon 2, MDK 2, Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, Rayman 2: The Great Escape, Dead or Alive 2

186372.Name: Official Sega Dreamcast Magazine Vol. 5: May 2000

186374.Name: Official Sega Dreamcast Magazine Vol. 7: September 2000

186375.Name: Official Sega Dreamcast Magazine Vol. 8: November 2000

186376.Name: Official Sega Dreamcast Magazine Vol. 9: December 2000

186377.Name: Official Sega Dreamcast Magazine Vol. 11: February 2001

186378.Name: Dreamcast Express Extra
186378.Overview:
Dreamcast Express Extra is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc released as part of the Dreamcast Express series.
Playable Demos - Cool Boarders Burrrn, Shutokou Battle, Sonic Adventure International, SoulCalibur, Chu Chu Rocket / Videos - Shenmue, Space Channel 5, DreamFlyer, Virtua Striker 2 ver.2000.1, Seaman: Kindan no Pet

186379.Name: Dreamcast Express Vol. 2
186379.Overview:
Dreamcast Express Vol. 2 is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc released as part of the Dreamcast Express series.
Videos - Pro Yakyuu Team o Tsukurou!, J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurou! (Dreamcast), Frame Gride, Seaman: Kindan no Pet, Maken X, The King of Fighters: Dream Match 1999, Airforce Delta, D no Shokutaku 2, UnderCover AD2025 Kei
VMU Data - Chou Hatsumei Boy Kani Pan: Bousou Roboto no Nazo!?, Climax Landers / Special - Tokyo Game Show '99 Spring, Interview with Hidekazu Yukawa & CM Making
Disc 2 - Frame Gride Test Operation Disc (Tainkenban)

186381.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 9
186381.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 9 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.9) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2000-12-29.
Playable Demos - Never 7: The End of Infinity, Gunspike, Mars Matrix, Daytona USA 2001 / Videos - Daytona USA 2001, Ecco the Dolphin: Defender of the Future, Fighting Vipers 2, Planet Harriers

186382.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 10
186382.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 10 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.10) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2001-02-09.
Playable Demos - Hundred Swords, Battle Beaster, Ultimate Fighting Championship, Aero Dancing i / Videos - Shenmue II, Eldorado Gate Vol. 1, SGGG

186383.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 11
186383.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 11 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.11) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Dreamcast Magazine issue #2001-03-30.
Playable Demos - World Series Baseball 2K1, Power Jet Racing 2001 / Videos - Sakura Taisen 3: Paris wa Moeteiru ka (Opening & Special movie), Bounty Hunter Sarah: Holy Mountain no Teiou, Eldorado Gate Vol. 4, NFL 2K1, NBA 2K1, Wild Riders / VMU Data - Eternal Arcadia, Atsumare! Guru Guru Onsen

186384.Name: Dorimaga GD Vol. 12
186384.Overview:
Dorimaga GD Vol. 12 (ドリマガＧＤ Vol.12) is a Japanese Sega Dreamcast demo disc distributed with Drimaga 2001-Vol3.
Playable Demos - Confidential Mission / Videos - Shenmue 2, Sonic Adventure 2, Taisen Net Gimmick: Capcom & Psikyo All Stars, Candy Stripe, Club Kart

186400.Name: Dreamcast Promotion Disk
186400.Overview: Dreamcast Promotion Disk is a promotional disc for the Sega Dreamcast. While the disc is designed for Sega's console, it merely contains video clips rather than doing anything unique with the hardware.

190503.Name: 4x4 Jam
190503.Overview: This unlicensed game for the Sega Dreamcast is an open world, go anywhere point to point off road racing title that throws steep inclines, unseen chasms, open plains and forested areas at drivers as they attempt to make it from one point to another on the non-linear circuit.

191330.Name: Cave Story
191330.Overview:
Cave Story is a metroidvania platformer with the amnesiac soldier Quote finding a city of rabbits called Mimigas. The Mimigas are preyed on by an evil doctor, who kidnaps them for his evil experiments. They still remember Arthur, a hero from their past and others are awaiting for the return of Dragons. The soldier soon falls in with Sue, a stranger to the Mimigas, but the only one who seems to know about the Dragon Eggs. Unfortunately the doctor wants her next.

The game closely resembles a NES platformer with a distinct 8-bit style and fast gameplay. The main character collects weapons (blade, bubbler, fireball, machine gun, nemesis, (super) missile launcher, polar star, snake, and spur) that can be leveled up three times. There are also health capsules to increase his life bar. There is a variety of jumping puzzles and boss battles to challenge players as they explore the game.

The DSiWare version of the game is fairly close to the original and does not contain most of the changes introduced in the earlier WiiWare release. It however contains the Sanctuary Time Attack mode, seasonal costumes for Christmas and Halloween, and a jukebox where all tracks of the game's soundtrack can be gradually unlocked.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Polykos Super Jelly Bean Quest in the Sketchbook of Illusion

191336.Name: Polyko's Super Jelly Bean Quest in the Sketchbook of Illusion
191336.Overview: This is a free game, originally developed by HotPengu and brought to the Dreamcast by Senile Team. In this small but charming game you control artist Polyko, who has been magically transported into the world of his own creations.

191340.Name: SQRXZ 2
191340.Overview:
Many players were happy to play Sqrxz on platforms never seen before and some of them even asked for more. The second part was born and can be considered a sequel.

Rodolphe, Simon and the new supporter, swedish chip tune artist Alexander Wiklund were brought together by Shahzad, who also did levels and testing, to form and develop the second part of Sqrxz.

Sqrxz 2 was born and initially released on Dreamcast. The release place was at tUM 2010 demoparty, where the game ranked 4th in the game development competition.

AlternateNames.AlternateName: Heroes of Might and Magic III

192100.Name: Heroes of Might and Magic III
192100.Overview:
Sega Dreamcast unreleased game Heroes of Might and Magic III. The Dreamcast port of Heroes of Might and Magic III: The Restoration of Erathia was planned, it was developed but very unfortunately it was canceled. 

This game would have been one of the best Dreamcast games in terms of quality. Wonderful music, great artwork, etc. Heroes III is considered the best game in the saga.

192350.Name: SQRXZ 3
192350.Overview: Sqrxz and his girlfriend were on a romantic adventure journey in a jungle somewhere here on our planet. All of a sudden Yve gets kidnapped by an evil power and Sqrxz is forced to collect dozens of shiny little rings to free her. The old ruins he has to explore are anything else than safe. Traps are spread all over the place… and… Sqrxz is not alone!

196206.Name: The SImpsons Bug Squad
196206.Overview: A leaked prototype of "The Simpson's Bug Squad" dumped from a Dreamcast dev kit used to pitch to Fox which never got commisioned.

199536.Name: Rush Rush Rally Reloaded
199536.Overview: Rush Rush Rally Reloaded is a 2D racing game for the SEGA Dreamcast. It is an enhanced version of the acclaimed Rush Rush Rally Racing, requested by fans and produced by Senile Team.

199735.Name: Xeno Crisis
199735.Overview: Xeno Crisis is inspired by similar arcade shooters like Smash TV and Shock Troopers, with art direction inspired by the Alien movie franchise. Featuring single or cooperative gameplay, one or two players play as unnamed space marines and work their way through seven levels in a scientific facility featuring procedurally generated rooms and levels, with a number of enemies of various difficulty in each room, concluding with a final boss battle at the end of most levels. After a player kills enemies on screen, a chance of an item, a weapon drop, health, or dogtags are dropped to aid the player. Dogtags are used as an in-game currency to help purchase upgrades like additional health or player speed. To increase the challenge to players, the starting machine gun has a limited amount of ammunition, and weapon pickups have a limited number of uses, requiring players to stay on the move and on the lookout for ammunition boxes.

200651.Name: Take the Bullet
200651.Overview: Take the Bullet was a planned First Person Shooter for Dreamcast from Red Lemon Studios. It also had an optional third-person view and was slated to have both online and split-screen multiplayer modes.

200933.Name: Super Boom Tread Troopers
200933.Overview: Play against up to three of your friends or enemies in an exclusive game developed especially for ODCM [Official Dreamcast Magazine] by Digital Eclipse.  Bounce bombs off the walls to destroy opposing forces and friends, and rack up the tank carcasses to get the high score.

200934.Name: Sweet Home
200934.Overview:
Sweet Home is a survival horror role-playing video game that was originally released for the Famicom in 1989. It features several elements of role-playing video games. Sweet Home was developed and published by Capcom and the game was never released outside Japan. The game is related to the Japanese horror film of the same name. 

What many call the grandfather of modern horror survival games, sweet home is a fine example of how details can make a simple game perfect. With a simple combat system, the game leads you to manage multiple teams and limited supplies of items in order to survive and espace the mansion. 

And beware, death is taken very seriously here! You die, you die, no going around it. 

So...do you have what it takes to discover the horrible secrets behind the paranormal activity and escape the mansion?

201108.Name: Gundam Side Story 0079: Rise from the Ashes: Special Edition
201108.Overview: This is the Special Edition of Gundam Side Story 0079: Rise from the Ashes otherwise known as the Bandai Best version which contains both the original release and the Premium Edition on one disc.

201295.Name: Castlevania: Resurrection
201295.Overview:
Castlevania: Resurrection, canceled in March 2000, was intended to be the seventeenth title of the Castlevania series for the short lived Sega Dreamcast console. This would also be the third Castlevania game, at the time, to enter the 3D realm.

The game was to focus on Sonia Belmont and a new character, Victor Belmont, an 1800s vampire hunter who had abandoned his lineage. The story is set in 1666, directly before Simon Belmont's adventure in the original Castlevania.

Greg Orduyan, the art director for the game, is so far the only staff member on the project to speak of how it would have worked out. Its cancelation is credited to many things, including disagreements between the Japanese and American Konami teams, and the death of the Dreamcast to the announcement of the Sony PlayStation 2.
